Politicians have turned a blind eye and made empty promises to rural Americans for too long, with devastating consequences for their communities.

Rural America deserves a partner in the White House‚Äîand in my administration they'll get one. Here's how: https://medium.com/@SenGillibrand/1f88697538b9

We are not the only country with video games. We are the only country where you can buy a weapon of war without any difficulty. Campaign finance data is already public. Getting an A from the NRA is disqualifying. This is the hottest summer on record. Nazis are bad. Still.

I want Washington to work for communities all over the country‚Äîand make sure every community has the resources it needs to thrive. Together, we can make big improvements in the lives of rural Americans.
Agriculture has become one of the biggest polluters in our economy, thanks to decades of failed policy. By paying farmers to fight climate change and investing in R&D we can tackle climate change.

I have plans that will help bring affordable housing, child care, and accessible banking to rural communities. My new approach to trade policy will make sure we're keeping good jobs here in America and giving rural communities a voice in trade negotiations.

A whole bunch of my other plans will help rural communities, too. My plan to cancel student loan debt and provide free public college will help young people build a future in rural communities, instead of driving them to cities to find a job that can pay down their debt.

Here‚Äôs my new approach: Guaranteeing farmers a fair price‚Äîraising farm incomes and reducing taxpayer expenses. We'll pay farmers for sustainable farming that protects our environment and provide consumers with affordable, local food. https://medium.com/@teamwarren/a-new-farm-economy-8db50fac0551

Finally, I've got a plan to overhaul our country's failed approach to the farm economy. For decades, government policy has subsidized industrial agriculture at taxpayers' expense while driving environmentally unsustainable farming practices and starving farmers.

This ends when I‚Äôm president. I'll create a public option for broadband and make sure every home has affordable high-speed internet. I'll crack down on anti-competitive practices and appoint FCC Commissioners who'll restore net neutrality and provide open access to the internet.

One of the best tools to expand access to health care‚Äîand unlock other economic opportunities‚Äîis high-speed internet. But big broadband companies exclude entire communities‚Äîespecially tribal communities and communities of color‚Äîfrom fast, reliable internet access.

I'll also tackle consolidation in health care. If a proposed merger is a first step to closing hospitals or slashing basic services, then a Warren administration will block it. And I'll invest more resources in community health centers and closing today‚Äôs rural doctor shortage.

My plan starts with protecting access to health care in rural communities, which are rapidly losing access to basic services. That's why I support #MedicareForAll‚Äîand why I'll increase Medicare reimbursement rates to help rural hospitals stay afloat.

Everyone should have the opportunity to build a good life wherever they live. But as giant corporations and Washington keep cutting off opportunities for huge parts of the country, the shot to succeed gets further out of reach for rural families. I've got a plan to fix that.

I'm kicking off my Iowa road trip today! As we head into Iowa, I'm sharing my new plans to invest in rural communities. It's time to put their interests ahead of giant companies and Wall Street. https://medium.com/@teamwarren/my-plan-to-invest-in-rural-america-94e3a80d88aa

It‚Äôs shameful that Americans are paying higher prescription drug prices than other countries. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm fighting in the Senate to increase competition in the market and lower costs.
https://www.cbsnews.com/news/drug-prices-in-2019-are-surging-with-hikes-at-5-times-inflation/

These health care costs are squeezing too many families. Recently, we passed bipartisan legislation in the Senate Finance Committee to begin taking on Big Pharma. This is promising, but there‚Äôs far more work to do to ensure that our health care system works for all Americans.

Krista of Keene and her son both have a rare connective tissue disorder. Her son faces other medical challenges, as well. The two have medications that insurance won't cover, meaning they have to pay hefty fees out of pocket.

Laura also depends on a monthly shot. A single dose was originally priced at $35,000 before she negotiated with the pharmaceutical company. 
 
She continues to live in fear that the temporary agreement will shift, leaving her stuck with a hefty fee.

Laura of Hollis has lived with a rare disease since she was 8. Now 60, she has managed it through a relatively inexpensive prescription. But when a big pharmaceutical company bought the patent, the price raised to $1,500 a month. 
 
And that's not the only medication she needs...

I sat down with Laura and Krista in Peterborough to talk about health care costs. Time and time again, I hear outrageous stories from Granite Staters about the skyrocketing costs of their care.
 
Learn more about Laura and Krista's stories below üëá http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EBZD9_VXUAAnZrx.jpg

But it is incredibly important that we recognize that perfectly normal, good people are capable of aiding racism & white supremacy.

Recognizing that is not about pillorying people. It‚Äôs about learning to recognize *the virus* & end an oppressive system designed to hurt us *all.*

What this moment is asking of us is to discuss *white supremacy and racism* as much - or possibly more than - *white supremacists and racists.*

When we do that, I believe we will start to make progress.

Recognizing white supremacy in ourselves - our institutions, our subconscious, our own past remarks or acts (no matter how consciously unintentional), is what makes the healing work ahead challenging. 

But it is not impossible,and confronting it is the only way to move forward.

Perhaps more than the obvious last steps of the supremacist,we must examine the nuance of their first steps.

That is a painful inquiry, bc for many, we may see familiarity in those first steps. And that familiarity is very difficult to see + admit. We‚Äôd rather not talk about it.

Healing ourselves of white supremacy will be hard. It will be hard because it requires us to confront *ourselves.*

We wish it was as simple as denouncing a white hood, a burnt cross, vile language. But we need to address where supremacy *begins,* not just where it ends.

White supremacy is often subconscious. & Clearly, our nation has not been inoculated. WS is our nation‚Äôs original sin;the driving logic of slavery, of Native genocide, of Jim Crow, of segregation, of mass incarceration,of ‚ÄúSend Her Back.‚Äù

It never went away. It was just dormant.

There is a difference between white supremacists & white supremacy.

White supremacy is like a virus. 

Supremacists are those who have been completely overcome by the disease, but supremacy - the virus - exists on a larger scale beyond just the infected. It also lays dormant.
